loan.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Mr. Vorn V. and his wife married in 1998. They have three children: two sons and one daughter, all of whom are in school. The family live about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Vorn and his wife have been fish wholesalers for eight years. They buy fish for resale to retailers at markets in Phnom Penh. They carry their goods in their old truck. Now, Mr. Vorn wants to buy a new truck to replace the old one.
Mr. Vorn is requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to add in his own savings to buy a new truck to replace the old one to use in his business.

loan.use: To add in his own savings for buying a truck for carrying fish

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Sreymao

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymao Y. and her husband married in 1985. They have six children: one son and five daughters. Three of their daughters work in a garment factory, the son is a construction worker, and other two children are in school. The family live in an old house about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Sreymao and her husband work in a brick kiln in the village. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $600 to repair her house.

loan.use: For repairing the house

loan.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun K. and her husband married in 1970. They have six children:one son and five daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home and three children live under their roof and help them in doing farming. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Soeun and her husband have been doing farming almost thirty years. They grow jasmine flowers and bananas on the farm near their home. Besides farming, Mrs. Soeun sells jasmine flowers at market in Phnom Penh. She buys jasmine flowers from farmers in the village for resale.
Mrs. Soeun is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 for purchasing jasmine flowers from farmers.

loan.use: To purchase jasmine flowers from farmers.

loan.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Yoeun S. and his wife married in 2001. They have three children: two sons and one daughter. The family lives along Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Yoeun and his wife have been weavers for six years. Itâ€™s a skill they learned from their relatives. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village who sells them in Phnom Penh. Besides weaving, Yoeun buys horse for resale as well.
He is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase silk materials for weaving and for buying horses to resale.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and to buy horses for resale.

loan.name: Sam-Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-oeun M. and his wife married in 1981. They have four children: two sons and two daughters. One daughter is fully employed and two children are in school and help them in the business when they are free from their studies and the youngest one stays at home. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Sam-oeun and his wife have been selling fruit for five years. They buy mangoes and sapodillas from farmers in the village and sell them at a market in Phnom Penh.
Mr. Sam- oeun is requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to purchase fruit for resale.

loan.use: To purchase fruit for resale

loan.name: Keat

texts.en:
Mr. Keat B., age 34, has not married yet and lives with his elderly mother. He owns a plot of farmland and is growing rice. After farming, he also works purchasing and sly recycled items from door to door in his community, normally earning a combned profit of around $2 a day.

However, he needs money to purchase fertilizer to use on his farm. The fertilizer would make the crops grow faster, so he decided to borrow from Kiva to purchase fertilizer. When he has enough capital, he will purchase pigs, chickens and ducts to breed.

Mr. Keat B. and his elderly mother appear in the photo.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loan.name: Salelavalu Uta Centre â€“ Group 2

texts.en:
For these 6 women of Salelavalu Uta on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women are requesting the loans for the following purposes:

Faimafili O., 54, is married to a farmer and they have 8 children together. She will be using her first loan to purchase iron roofing, timber, nails and cement in order to build a food stall. At the stall, she will sell cabbages, coconuts, and other vegetables.

Gase S. (20, married, 1 child) wants to purchase a canoe, a pair of fins, fishing torch (flashlight), spear and goggles. She sells her fish at the Saelelologa market. Her keen knowledge of parts of the sea where the fish are located provides her with an edge over the competition.

Isapela S. (43, married, 4 children) intends to buy chemicals, a knife, and pots to sell potted plants, taro and bananas.

Manifo T. ( 19, single, no children) plans to use her loan to purchase iron roofing, nails and cement in order to build a shop to sell vegetables, coconuts, coconut oil and other products.

Malaine S. (26, married, 5 children) sells cabbages, tomatoes and cucumbers 5 days per week. With her loans, she will purchase seeds, weed killer, knives, a pick, a rake, a hose and other equipment to tend her vegetable garden.

Miriama T. (30, married, 5 children) creates Elei sarongs. Elei printing is a traditional Samoan method of fabric printing. She will make lavalava (wraparound skirt worn by men) using the sewing machine, plain sarongs; paints and x-ray films will be purchased with her loan.

loan.use: Purchase chemicals, weed killer, bush knives, etc

loan.name: Chong

texts.en: Chong S. is 38 years old and has lived in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia with her husband since 2002. She has one child who is a student. She works as construction worker building houses. Normally, she makes $2.50 a day of profit per day. Her husband, Mr. Kim Vart, head family, is also a construction worker, but he earns around $4 a day. This couple is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase cement to repair their house.

loan.use: To purchase cement to repair the house.

loan.name: Salelologa A Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
While SaleL., the capital village of Savaii Island, is largely semi-urbanized, its outlying areas are still agricultural. The SaleL. A Centre is located in a largely agricultural area and the people in the community still subsist on farming and vegetable gardening. For this group, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Betty A. (42, married, 6 children) works in the sewing business. With her loan, she will purchase a sewing machine, material and thread to produce puletasis (dresses), T-shirts and uniforms.

Legalo T. (28, married, 2 children) sells pancakes (round lumps of fried bread) twice a week. Her mother taught her to cook and her business is successful due to good taste, good service and lower prices. With her loan, she will purchase a bag of flour, a fryer, oil, sugar, baking soda and a mixing spoon.

Mina P L. (56, married, 7 children) also sells pancakes and ice cakes (ice cream) three times a week. She will use her loan to purchase a bag of flour, sugar, bucket of oil, a stove, a big bowl and a frying pan.

Miriama O. (63, married, 5 children) sells both food and clothing. Her daughter does the sewing. Her loan will allow her to purchase both cooking ingredients and sewing materials. She expects to earn a cash flow of 260 Tala (~104 USD) per week.

Sarai Aliitasi M. (67, married, 8 children) sells cigarettes twice a week. Her loan will allow her to purchase 250 cigarettes and 50 plastic bags.

Valelei S. (64, married, 10 children) sells BBQ chicken, sauce and lamb chops. Her loan will be used to purchase oil, soy sauce, plastic plates and other materials for her business.

loan.use: Purchase a fryer, oil, sugar, baking soda, etcâ€¦.

loan.name: Salelologa I Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
While Salelologa, the capital village of Savaii Island, is largely semi-urbanized, its outlying areas are still agricultural. The Salelologa I Centre is located in a largely agricultural area and the people in the community still subsist on farming and vegetable gardening. For this group, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Fiapule L., 31, has 2 children and is married. She has 3 years of experience in her business of Elei printing, a traditional Samoan way of fabric printing, which produces Elei sarongs (skirts). With her loan, she will purchase 5 Elei x-ray dryers, 2 Elei boards, 3 cans of paint and material. She plans to earn a net cash flow of 110 Tala (~44 USD) per week.

Susana T., 33, has 4 children and a husband who is a vegetable garden farmer. She sells vegetables, coconuts and other products from her shop. With her loans, she will purchase wire, a bag of fertilizer, a bag of seeds, 2 rakes, 2 spades and a wheelbarrow. She plans to earn a net cash flow of 110 Tala (~44 USD) per week.

Fialuma T., 20, is single. She produces ice cakes (ice cream) to sell to school children. With her loan, she will purchase a license, 2 bags of sugar, 22 paper cups, 2 candy bags and 3 dried mangos. She plans to earn a net cash flow of 170 Tala (~68 USD) per week.

Fatufua L., 28, is married with 2 children. She has over 5 years of experience in sewing. She sews lavalava (wraparound skirt worn by men), puletasis (dresses) and shirts. With her loan, she will purchase a sewing machine, spool of thread, fabric/materials, paints and Elei designs. She expects a net weekly cash flow of 250 Tala (~ 100 USD).

Vaifale F., 20, has no children. She sells taro, bananas and yams to the people of his village. With her loan, she will purchase weed killer, chemicals, 2 bush knives and 2 spades.

loan.use: Purchase fabric, Elei x-ray dryers, paints, Elei boards, etc.

loan.name: Faaea

texts.en: Faaea F., 38, is married with 7 children. Her husband is a driver at the airport. She wishes to start selling produce (cabbages, tomatoes, cucumbers, etc.) 5 days a week. She will use her loan to purchase weed killer, a wheelbarrow, cabbage seeds, tomato seeds, pumpkin seeds, cucumber seeds and peppers.

loan.use: Purchase weed killer, pesticides, etc.

loan.name: Salelologa E Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
Salelologa is the capital village of Savaii Island. The central market, the wharf, and the bus station are located in Salelologa. The hub of retail business is also in this village. Therefore, a large number of households are engaged in retail businesses which target neighbouring villages. The women in this group are engaged in retail businesses. Most of the commodities sold in Saleloga are purchased from the capital town, Apia, which is located across the island of Upolu. The members of this group have already undergone the required 4 session training from SPBD and are ready to receive their loans to expand and improve their retail businesses.

The Salelologa E Centre is located in a largely agricultural area and the people in the community still subsist on farming and vegetable gardening. The women who formed the Salelologa E Centre are determined to improve their present living conditions. With the help of small loans from SPBD they will be able to upgrade their farms and vegetable gardens and also expand into other income-generating activities including: sewing, Elei printing, and pancake-making. These activities are a good way of augmenting their household income.

Sieni F. (53, married, 5 children) wants to purchase sugar, salt, onions, soup, flour, potatoes, and noodles to sell at the Salelologa market.

Sulu M. (45, married, 9 children) needs equipment for her cattle and pig farm.

Mele M. P. (41, widowed, 2 children) sells pork cakes and pancakes (round lumps of fried dough). She needs a stove, flour, sugar, oil and other ingredients to bake the cakes.

Aotoa F. (28, married, 1 child) produces ice cakes (ice cream). She will use her loan to purchase plastic cups, sugar and other materials.

Asenati Masoe P. (32, married, 1 child) sells ice cakes and pancakes. She will use her loan to buy a stove, flour, and other materials.

Tuisuesue V. (40, married, 8 children) will use her loan to sell pancakes and coffee.

loan.use: Purchase ovens, flour, sugar and other baking materials, etc.

loan.name: Satupaitea Pitonuu Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
For these 3 women of Satupaitea Pitonuu on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Sevai M., 38, is married with 4 children. She has over 4 years experience selling ice cakes (ice cream) and cigarettes. With her loan, she will purchase sugar, concentrate, cartons, and plastic cups.

Alefa S., 29, is married to a carpenter. They have 2 children together. She has 8 years of experience in the retail business. She sells various food items, drinks, taro, and bananas at her shop. With her loan, she will purchase flour, sugar, an oven, oil, soda powder, and 2 spoons.

Tavaetoto E., 32, is married with 3 children. She has over 5 years experience in farming her plantation. She produces taro, bananas and yams and sells them at the Salelologa market twice per week. Her loan will be used to purchase weed killer, pesticides, 2 knives, an axe, a banana spray, and fertilizer.

loan.use: Purchase flour, sugar, an oven, oil, etc.

loan.name: Som

texts.en:
Som S. is 24 years old and has lived with her children and her husband in Kampong Cham province for many years. She is a housewife who stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family. She makes no income for the family.

Her husband, Suon Sorka, who covers all the daily expenses for the family, works as motorbike dealer. On average, he earns about $8 a day of income from his work. He has only one little child. Beside being a broker, he also knows how to cut hair, so he wants to make an extra income by opening a small stand and purchasing some equipment to cut hair. With the remainder of the loan, he will buy a motorbike to sell.

loan.use: To open a haircutting stand and to purchase a motorbike for resale

loan.name: Iva A Centre - Group 4

texts.en:
For these 2 women of Iva on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They both undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account ,and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Samoana S., 43, is married with no children. Her husband is both a farmer and a fisherman. Her loan will be used to buy equipment to support starting businesses in both of these fields. She will purchase pesticides, a knife, goggles, a spear and a wheelbarrow.

Seulata A., 47, is married with 4 children. She is starting a business selling taro, yams, bananas and other produce. Her loan will be used to purchase weed killer, pesticides, and a wheelbarrow. Her family has been growing vegetables for years, so it will not be a difficult business to start.

loan.use: Purchase weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, etc.

loan.name: Mohammad Nasir

texts.en: Mohammad Nasir lives in District 5 of Kabul Afghanistan, where he is married and the father of two children. Although uneducated, he has extensive experience in agriculture and a large amount of cultivatable land. This is the season in Afghanistan when preparations for planting are underway, and because he wants to expand his business, Mohammad is requesting a loan to increase his agricultural stock. The increased income will help make the lives of his family members better, and will make possible the future education of his two sons. He thanks you for your support.

loan.use: To expand his agricultural stock

loan.name: Nhoem

texts.en:
Nhoem K. B., 33, is a widow and lives with her two children. She works at a karaoke parlor, where she has been playing songs for the customers for over 5 years. Including her tips, she earns around $8 a day. Her children are students.

When she was young, she learned how to do make up and she used to be on staff at hair dresser shop, so she knows how to be a hair dresser. To generate an extra income, she decided to take a loan from Kiva to purchase powder and some hairdressing equipment to serve the people around her house when she is not working at the karaoke bar.

loan.use: To purchase hairdressing equipment

loan.name: AiÅ¡a

texts.en: AiÅ¡a was born in 1976 and she is married. Her husband is a full-time employee and earns 800 KM (about US$ 650)monthly. They have no additional earnings. AiÅ¡a has one son who is going to primary school. This is their fourth loan through the Organization WWI, and the present loan they are requesting is for US$ 1200. AiÅ¡a wants to use the loan for raising chickens in order to increase their living standard and improve the financial situation of her family.

loan.use: For raising chickens

loan.name: Sili 1 Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
For these 2 women of Sili 1 on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They both undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Faitala T., 27, is married with 3 children. She has over 10 years of involvement in the taro, banana and yam business. She sells her produce at the Salelologa market once a week. With her loan, she wishes to purchase weed killer, pesticides, wire, 2 knives, and fertilizer.

Faigalotu T., 28, is married with 4 children. For more than 5 years, she has been selling taro, bananas, and chips to people shopping at the market. Her family is very well respected for the quality of its produce. With her loan, she intends to purchase a machete, a cap, a frying pan, an oven, plastic bags, a scraper, a scoop, and an iron.

loan.use: Purchase weed killer, a machete, an oven, etc.

loan.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan N. is 30 years old and has lived with her family for over 10 years in Kampong Cham province. She has two children who are students. She raises the familyâ€™s income by selling fish in a busy market, normally receiving $4 of profit per day. Actually, she sells fish only in the morning and, afterwards, she is a good wife cooking food for the whole family and sometimes teaching her children after school. Her husband, Pen Sarun, 34, is a taxi driver (Kampong Cham to Phnom Penh) and makes $5 a day.

To expand the business and facilitate transportation, she would request a loan. Part of the loan will be used to purchasing more fish for her fish-selling business. With the remainder, she will buy a motorbike for shipping the fish.

Chan N. appears in the photo with her husband.

loan.use: To purchase more fish and a motorbike.

loan.name: HadÅ¾ira

texts.en: HadÅ¾ira was born in 1959 and she is married. Her husband works a full-time job in a mine and earns 800 KM (about US$ 650) monthly. They have one son, unemployed. This is her fourth loan through the Organization WWI. The amount of the present loan she is requesting is US$ 1200. HadÅ¾ira wants to use it for buying chickens, in order to expand her business.

loan.use: For buying chickens

loan.name: HadÅ¾ira

texts.en: HadÅ¾ira was born in 1945 and she is married. Her husband is retired and his monthly pension is 400 KM (about US$ 325). Their additional income is from selling milk, which brings in 150 KM (about US$ 120) monthly. HadÅ¾ira has 2 children, one son and a daughter. She wants to use this loan in the amount of US$ 1200 for buying a calf and chickens, in order to produce healthy and quality food for her family.

loan.use: For buying a calf and chickens

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy additional clothes for re-sale

loan.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng M., age 50, is a mother of six children and has resided in Phnom Penh over 30 years. To raise the familyâ€™s income, she works growing rice and raising fish to earn approximately $1 a day. Her husband, Ouy Mao, age 54, works as farmer growing rice. Normally, he makes $5 a day in revenue. Two of their children are employed by a garment factory with a salary $70 each per month and the rest are students and farmers.

To help with their farm, this couple would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase a harvest machine. This will be used to hire to the local people to gain more profit for the family.

loan.use: To purchase a harvest machine.

loan.name: Rusmira

texts.en: Rusmira was born in 1983 and she is married. She lives in a small village called TiÅ¡ina, near the town of Zenica. Rusmira has two children, 7 months and 4 years old. Their family's only income is her husband's meager salary. She has requested a loan in the amount of US$ 1200. Rusmira wants to use it for buying cattle. Her wish is to expand the business and increase monthly income for her household.

loan.use: For buying cattle

loan.name: Jaweed

texts.en: Jaweed lives in District 11 of Kabul Afghanistan with his wife and son. He has a car parts shop in a busy area of the city, and in order to better serve his customers and expand his business, he is requesting a loan to import additional parts. With the increased income, Jaweed will be better able to support his family. He thanks all for their support.

loan.use: To import more auto parts

loan.name: Biubwa

texts.en:
Biubwa is 27 years old and is married woman. Biubwa conducts small business, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 30 years old, divorced, and has 2 children. She supplies goods to other businesses, and began her business in 1994. She works everyday at 6 AM to 3:30 PM. She earns a total of $140 in profits from her sales every month.

She now would like a loan to increase the number of goods in her business.

loan.use: To buy more goods for her business.

loan.name: Khaduji

texts.en:
Khaduji is a 22 year old single woman. Khaduji conduct some small business, starting in 2005. She works from 6am to 6pm everyday at her business and earns about $70 a month from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more comodities for her business.

loan.use: To buy more comodities for her business.

loan.name: Khairiya's Wastara Group

texts.en:
Khairiya is 47 years old and is a married woman with 1 child aged 12 years old. Khairiya runs a small business that she started in 2003. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma and Amina, who have businesses dealing in small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Khairiya's Wastara Group

texts.en:
Khairiya is 47 years old and is married woman with 1child, age 12 years old. Khairiya conduct some small business, she started in 2003. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma and Amina, who have businesses dealing in small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Fatma's Wapendanao Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 47 years old and is a married woman with no children. She and her husband take care of 5 other people, varying in age between 50-80 years old. Fatma conduct small business, starting in 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Khadija.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business

loan.name: Fatma's Wapendanao Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 47 years old and is married woman with no children. She and her husband take care of 5 other people, ages 50-80 years old. Fatma conduct small business, she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Khadija, who have business dealing in small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business

loan.name: Kisa

texts.en: Kisa is 39 years old and is divorced woman with 3 children, aged 15-25 years old. Kisa has been running the business that she started in 1994. Everyday she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Imani

texts.en:
Imani is 47 years old and is a married woman with 10 children, varying in age between 10-30 years old. Imani is a business woman, who started in 2002. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for he business.

loan.name: Masika's Umoja Ni Nguvu Yetu. Group

texts.en:
Masika is 38 years old, married, and has 1 child. Masika owns small business, which she began in 2005. She begins work at 10 AM, and ends at 8 PM. She earns a total of $200 in profits from her sales.

Masika now hopes for a loan to purchase more items for her business. She will share this loan with sub-group members Amina and Chekanao, who run their own small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 29 years old and is married. Starting in 2007, Mariam has been a business woman. She works from 6am to 6pm every day.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Azhghar Shah

texts.en: Azhghar Shah lives with his family in District 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has been leasing a retail shop for more than two years, but now requests a loan to complete his purchase of the store in order to increase his profits, thereby enabling him to better support his family. He thanks you for your support.

loan.use: To complete his lease purchase

loan.name: Asia's Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Asia is 38 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, aged 7,10,16,and 18. She and her husband also take care of one other person, who is 22 years old. Asia owns a general store, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Zahra's Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Zahra is 35 years old, married, and has 5 children. Zahra owns a small shop, called Khanga, which she started in 2005. Everyday she begins at 8 AM and ends at 8 PM. She earns a total of $90 in profits a month from her business.

Zahra is now hoping for a loan to purchase more items for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member Fatma, who also runs a small business herself.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Nargis' Group

texts.en:
Nargis M., a mother of five (four daughters and one son), lives with her family in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. Her husband works at a brick furnace for a meager income. Nargis has been a borrower at Asasah for the past two years, her last loan having been used to purchase a cow. She now needs another loan to buy an additional cow.

Nargis is a group leader of four other women, who are: Shaheen B., who will buy sheep with her share of the loan; Ameera B., who wants to expand the familyâ€™s vegetable business; Shazia B., who requires this loan for her embroidered clothes business, and Khadija B., who wants to buy a washing machine for her laundry.

loan.use: To purchase a cow

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loan.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mr. Kosal L. and his wife, Sokheang Kan married in 1982. They have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of their children were employing weaving scarves in the village and other three children stay at home. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Kosal has been raising ducks in a farm near the house for three years. His wife has been employed planting small trees for three years too.
Mr. Kosal is requesting a loan in the amount of $250 to purchase baby pigs and ducks for raising.

loan.use: To purchase baby pigs and ducks for raising

loan.name: Raya's Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Raya is 34 years old and is a married woman with 7 children, whose ages range from 1-18 years old. Raya owns a small clothing shop, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members.

loan.use: To buy more cloth for her shop.

loan.name: Savun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savun M. and her husband married in 1986. They have three children: one son and two daughters. One of her daughters is a hairdresser and other two children are in school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Savun has been selling groceries since 1999 and has been a silk weaver since 1982. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to a middle man in the village who sells it in Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Savun is requesting a loan in the amount of $200 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loan.use: To purchase grocery items for resale

loan.name: Mwashamba's Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Mwashamba is 23 years old, and married. She began her business in 2007, and works daily from 7:30 AM to 8 PM at night. She earns around $170 a month from her sales.

Mwashamba now is requesting a loan to increase the number of items she stocks in her business. She will also share the money from the loan with her sub-group members, all who run their own small businesses as well.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Mwashamba's Tuvumiliane Group

texts.en:
Mwashamba is 23 years old and is married. Mwashamba is a business woman, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7.30am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy moreitems for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Lum

texts.en:
Mrs. Lum C. is widow with three children: one son and two daughters. Her son is married and lives outside the family home. One of her daughters works in a garment factory and other one weaves silk at home. The family lives on an island on Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Lum has been a weaver since 1979. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to a middle man in the village who sells it in Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Lum is requesting a loan in the amount of $700.00 to repair some part of her house.

loan.use: For repairing some part of her house

loan.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
I am Naseem F., a mother of seven girls and one boy, and I reside with my family in the small town of Borewala, Pakistan. My elder girls dropped school due to some family problems, but the younger girls still attend, while my son runs a salon, a business he has operated for the last four years. The only income earner of the family, he works very hard to improve our financial situation, and he currently needs to renovate his salon and buy chairs and tables for it.

I have been joined by two other women in my loan group: Razia B., who will buy wood, and Khursheed B., a widow who is borrowing for her daughterâ€™s embroidery business.

loan.use: To renovate the existing salon

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Mov

texts.en:
Mr. Mov E. and his wife married in 1988. They have three children; one son and two daughters. All of their children are in school. The family lives about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Mov and his wife make Khmer noodles for selling. They have been doing this business for seven years.
Mr. Mov is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase rice for making Khmer noodle.

loan.use: To purchase rice for making Khmer Noodle

loan.name: Kheang

texts.en:
Mr. Kheang S. and his wife married in 2000. They have one son who is in school. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Kheang has been a driver for a company for many years. He carries goods from Phnom Penh to sell in other provinces. His wife stays at home takes care of children.
He is requesting a loan in the amount of $1200 for repairing his house.

loan.use: For repairing his house

loan.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en: Jameela I. is the leader of a group of three women and the mother of two boys and one girl .Her eldest child is a day laborer; her daughter stays at home, while her youngest son attends a local school. Jameela has been a client of Asasah, a microfinance institution, for one year. With her first loan, she bought a donkey cart, and this year she will purchase a cow with her share of the loan. Jameelaâ€™s sub group members are: Shakila N., who is borrowing for her husbandâ€™s vegetables business, and Azra B., who will use her share of the loan to expand the family's flour store.

loan.use: To purchase a cow

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is 22 years old and is a single woman. Halima is a bite seller since 2004. Everyday, she works from 5am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en: Shahnaz S. is married and a mother of three children: two boys and one girl. Her eldest son attends Grade One at a local school while the other two are not yet of school age. Shahnazâ€™s husband works at a brick furnace, and currently she is borrowing to get an electric meter for her house. Her group members sharing in the loan are: Razia B., who will buy a dairy cow, and Munnawer B., who plans to buy a buffalo.

loan.use: To purchase an electric meter for her house

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Fatma's Tuzinduke Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 49 years old and is married with 2 children, 25 and 23 years old. Fatma owns a small charcoal store and has been a tailor since 2005. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and earns $400 each month from her sales.

Now, she hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who deal in small businesses

loan.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loan.name: Mariam's Tuzinduke Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 40 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, aged 12,18,22 and 26. Mariam owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loan.name: Ziada's Tuzinduke Group

texts.en:
Ziada is 31 years old, married, and has 4 young children. Ziada sells fresh fish, and began her business in 2007. Everyday she works from 7 AM to 4 PM at her business, and earns around $110 a month from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to increase the number of fishes she can sell at her business. She will also share the money from the loan with her co-group members, Mariam and Ashura, who both run small businesses as well.

loan.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loan.name: Rehema's Tuzinduke Group

texts.en:
Rehema is 34 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged, 11,15 and 16. Rehema runs a business, which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more comodities for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mayasa.

loan.use: To buy more comodities for her business.

loan.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 39 years old, married, and has 5 children. She and her husband also care for an older individual, who is 63 years old. She began her business in 2003, and has been working from 5 AM to 11 PM daily to keep her business running. She earns about a total of $110 each month.

Amina would like to request a loan to increase her businessâ€™ inventory.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Rahma's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Rahma is 30 years old and is a married woman with 5 children, aged 9-17 years old. Rahma is a bites and coconut oil seller, who started the business in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Astou

texts.fr:
Mrs. D. prepares food for sale. Her sales point has been located near the neighborhood open-air market Baye Laye in Guediawaye for two years. Her clientele is composed principally of vendors from the nearby market. She is presently on her third loan and has never been late with a payment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mme D. est une restauratrice installee a cote du marche du quartier BAYE LAYE A Guediawaye depuis deux ans. Sa cliente est principalement constituee de commercants dudit marche. elle en est a son troisieme credit sans aucun retard de paiement.

loan.use: serving food to market vendors

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Grace's Alovera Group

texts.en:
Grace, age 40, is single with one son of six years. She has a charcoal business that she started one and a half years ago and she also began selling food two months ago. Grace works from 7am to 6pm daily, and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $45 from her work.

Grace hopes to take out a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more food to sell. She will share this loan with her group, Alovera, whose members sell fish, cooking utensils, shops, quarry, charcoal boutique, cosmetics and broilers. This group has a total of 19 members.

In the picture, Grace is sitting in the front row, fourth from the left.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more food stock

loan.name: Elvisa

texts.en: Elvisa lives in a small village near the town of Doboj. She has one child, 12 years old. Elvisa gets a monthly child allowance in the amount of 150 KM (about US$ 120). This is her first loan through MCO WWI in the amount of US$ 500. She intends to buy seeds for farming. She plans to produce food and reduce costs in this way.

loan.use: To buy seeds

loan.name: Lamine

texts.fr:
Mr. N. is an auto mechanic in the Baye Laye neighborhood. His clientele is composed of individuals who own cars as well as of taxi owners. He is requesting his second loan, after having correctly reimbursed the preceding one.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

M. N. exerce le metier de mecanicien au quartier Baye Laye. Sa clientele est constitue aussi bien de particuluers que de vehicule de taxis urbains. il en est a son deuxieme credit apres avoir paye correctement le precedent.

loan.use: development of his little auto repair business

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loan.name: Ramiza

texts.en: Ramiza is a 39-year-old woman who lives near the town of Å½ivinice. She is a widow and she lives together with her father-in-law and with her younger son who goes to secondary school. Ramiza has monthly pension in the amount of 700 KM (about US$ 550) and she gets 300 KM (about US$ 240) from her older son who lives in Switzerland. This is her first loan through MCO WWI in the amount of US$ 825. Ramiza is going to buy chickens for fattening and 2 or 3 sheep. She needs some kind of commitment to make good use of her free time and to improve the material status of her family.

loan.use: To buy chickens for fattening

loan.name: Suvada

texts.en: Suvada was born in 1990 and lives in Å½ivinice. She is married and her husband is a full-time employee with a monthly income of 600 KM (about US$ 485). Their additional income is from her brother-in-law who lives with the family AvdibaÅ¡iÄ‡ and brings in 320 KM (about US$ 250). Suvada has one child, 3 months old. She wants to use this loan in the amount of US 825 for buying a heifer, in order to improve their livestock reserves from which they have significant monthly income.

loan.use: To buy a heifer

loan.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
B. Elizabeth is a trader who sells clothing materials. She is married and has 2 children. She is working very hard to support the family. She wishes to increase sales, but lacks funding to do so.

She is asking for $425 as an additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loan.use: As an additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43683

loan.name: Rosalina Arnaldo

texts.en:
Rosalina, or as she kindly introduced herself â€œRosaâ€, is 47-years-old and originally from Bela Vista, in the Maputo Province. She has been married for 2 years with her third husband. The first marriage lasted 5 years and Rosa had a girl, who unfortunately died one day after she was born. Rosa never had any children again.

After the Mozambican civil war was over, Rosa decided to come back to Maputo Province, where she felt she belonged. In 1995, Rosa moved to Ponta Dâ€™Ouro to look for work opportunity. Ponta Dâ€™Ouro is a beach village bordering South Africa famous for its tourism. For the past 11 years, Rosa has worked as a cook at the local diving camp from 5:00am to 4:00pm.

Rosaâ€™s monthly salary of 1,000 Rand (approximately US$140) was only raised twice in 11 years. She decided to ask for a loan to build her own cement house. This will be Rosaâ€™s third loan with Hluvuku, the first 2 were used to buy construction material and begin construction. This loan of MTn 10,000 will be used to buy aluminum roofing. Rosa believes that with 2 more loans she will be able to finish her house and conclude a lifetime dream.

loan.use: Buy construction material

loan.name: Abdalah's Jitahidi Msakuzi Group

texts.en:
Abdalah, age 35, is married and has a one-year-old son. He has a shop business that he began 4 years ago. He works from 6am to 10pm daily and has managed to make a monthly profit of about $136.

Abdalah has taken out 2 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his business and also to buy land. He hopes for a new loan to increase the capital for his shop. Abdalah will share this loan with his group Jitahidi Msakuzi, the members of which deal in selling fruits and vegetables, clothes, cereals, food, charcoal, fish and poultry. This group has a total of 11 members.

In the picture, Abdalah is standing 3rd from left.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more shop inventory

loan.name: Emilia

texts.en:
A. Emilia is a successful trader who owns a grocery store. She is married and has 4 dependents. She is working very hard to help meet the familyâ€™s financial needs. At the moment business is doing very well and she wishes to increase sales.

She is asking for $425 as an additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loan.use: As an additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43686

loan.name: Florentina Alberto

texts.en:
Florentina is 42 years old, originally from Xai-Xai in the Gaza Province. She married when she was 22 years old, but divorced in 1995. She had 2 children, the boy died when he was little and the girl is now 20 years old, married with 2 children and lives in Xai-Xai.

Florentina never worked before she got divorced. In 1995, she was hired as a cook for a construction company, and sent to Ponta Dâ€™Ouro to cook for the employees working in government construction. Ponta Dâ€™Ouro is a beach village bordering South Africa, famous for its tourism in the Maputo Province. After the construction was completed, Florentina was let go, but decided to stay on in Ponta. For the past 8 years she has been working in a house as a cleaning lady and guard. Her bosses live in Maputo and come to Ponta during weekends and long holidays. She earns MTn 1,500 per month.

Florentina heard about Hluvuku through a friend and decided to apply for a loan to build her house. Florentina lives at her bossesâ€™ house, and as she has never received a raise in her salary for the past 8 years, the loan will be the only way to start buying construction material. This is Florentinaâ€™s third loan and it will still be used to buy more construction material. She already has the land and intends to start construction with this loan.

In the future, Florentina would like to finish building her house and buy furniture, always counting on Hluvukuâ€™s loan. The picture shows Florentina with her cement blocks at her bossesâ€™ house.

loan.use: Buy construction material

loan.name: Evandre Celio Joaqui

texts.en:
Evandre is 24-years-old and originally from Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland and one of the most developed districts in the Maputo province. Evandre is single and currently lives with 3 younger sisters and his mom.

In 2002, soon after Evandre completed 10th grade in Namaacha, he moved to Manhica to attend a teacherâ€™s professional school. After 2 years he was granted a title to teach primary students up to 7th grade, focusing in mathematics for 6th and 7th grades. Evandre makes MTn 4,700 (around US$190) per month. His family is currently living with him, along with his sisters and mom, he also supports a nephew.

Although Evandre is happy with his new job and his lifeâ€™s progress, he feels that his income is not enough to start his dream, the construction of his own house. Evandre is very conscious that if he loses his job all his family wonâ€™t have a place to live. Therefore, Evandre approached Hluvuku for the first time, after hearing from his sister who is also a client. This loan of MTn 10,000 will be used to buy construction material and start construction. He already has the land, sand and stones and the architectâ€™s plan and approval to build his house. In the future, Evandre would like to build a studio adjacent to the house where he would be able to play music with his friends and eventually record.

loan.use: Buy construction material

loan.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah S. is one of the successful bakers in the town. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a security man and his income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family. Hannah is working very hard to support the familyâ€™s financial needs. She wants to increase her income.

She is asking for $525 as an additional capital to buy more supplies to increase sales.

loan.use: As an additional capital to buy more supplies to increase sales

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 43689

loan.name: Constantina Salvador

texts.en:
Constantina is 31-years-old, originally from Inhambane Province. She married in 2001, had a daughter in 2002 and in 2006 got divorced. In addition to supporting her 6-year-old child that goes to school (currently at 1st grade), Constantina also supports her two younger brothers that are studying (the oldest in 12th grade and the youngest in 7th grade).

Constantina studied until 6th grade in Inhambane, but due to her familyâ€™s financial difficulties, she had to stop school and work. She got a job as an assistant at the districtâ€™s educational administration. She started cleaning the offices and helping carrying documents around. She was promoted to administrative assistant and started to work only with clients and documents, filling out requests and other things. Currently she has a monthly salary of MTn 1,700 (around US$70), plus a house that was given to her to live, just adjacent to the administration office. She plans to go back to school one day so that she can finish 10th grade and be promoted again.

This will be Constantinaâ€™s second loan with Hluvuku. Constantina used the first loan of MTn 5,000 to buy construction material and start building her house. She is very conscious that if she gets fired she wonâ€™t have a place to live. This second loan of MTn 9,000 will still be used to buy more construction materials. Initially the house will have 2 bedrooms, a living room and bathroom. With a third loan, Constantina believes she will be able to buy all the roofing and move in. In the future, she would like more loans to furnish the house and expand to a 3-bedroom house.

loan.use: Buy construction material

loan.name: Abra

texts.en: Ms. Abra D. is 41 years old and a married mother of 3 children. She lives and works in the town of AdÃ©ta, a medium-sized town located about 150 kilometers from LomÃ©, the capital of Togo. Popular dress in Togo consists of a skirt and top cut and tailored from a length of fabric, and another length of fabric wrapped around the waist. These pieces of fabric, which are vibrantly colored and lightweight, are called â€˜pagnes.â€™ Selling pagnes is a popular business for women in Abraâ€™s region, as they travel to LomÃ© to purchase them to resell in the market in AdÃ©ta. With her loan Abra hopes to buy more pagnes in various prints and colors to increase her stock and continue to satisfy her loyal customers. The revenue generated from her increased sales will allow her to continue to send her 3 children to school and to improve the quality of her familyâ€™s life.

loan.use: To buy more pagnes (West African fabrics)

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: Buy merchandise at wholesales prices.

loan.name: Darling Mercedes

texts.es:
Darling G. C. is 32 years old, a single mother, and lives in one of the outlying neighborhoods in the city of Bluefields. For the past 10 years she has had a general store, with which she has been able to support and educate her two children who study at primary school. In the neighborhood where young Mrs. G. lives there are other stores, but the difference is that she has a variety of products and her strength is that besides basic goods, she sells meat, which no other store offers. For this reason, Mrs. G. is asking for a loan to buy the following: rice, sugar, flour, soft drinks, chicken, cold cuts, beef, ground meat, beef ribs and salami. Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.
Darling G. C. tiene 32 aÃ±os de edad, es madre soltera, habita en uno de los barrios perifericos de esta ciudad de Bluefields y desde hace 10 aÃ±os tiene una pulperia con la cual se ha mantenido y podido educar a sus dos hijos quienes estudian en nivel primario. En este sector que recide la joven seÃ±ora G. tambien hay otras pulperias, sin embargo la diferencia es que la solicitante tiene variedad de productos y su fuerte es ademas de granos basicos la venta de carne, producto que las otras pulperias no ofertan. Por tal razon la seÃ±ora G. solicita el financiamiento para comprar lo siguiente: arroz, azucar, harina, gaseosas, carne de pollo, mortadela , carne de res, carne molida, costilla de res y salchichon.

loan.use: Buy rice, sugar, flour, soft drinks, chicken, cold cuts, beef, ground meat, beef ribs and salami.

payment.comment: La cuota real es de US$ 100.62
la cuota real de pago es de $ 100.62 dÃ³lares.

loan.name: Issifou

texts.en: Issifou A. is 33 years old and the married father of 3 children. Two of his children are enrolled in primary school and one works with him in his store. To provide for his family, Issifou opened a general store in AdÃ¨ta, a medium-sized town located about 150 kilometers from LomÃ©, the capital of Togo. He sells a variety of items ranging from candies, soap and canned goods to prepaid cellphone cards. His store is located in the center of town and bustles with activity. With this loan, Issifou would like to replenish his stock and also enlarge his inventory. He hopes that by increasing his commercial activity he can respond to the needs of his family and to continue to participate in the development of his community.

loan.use: Replenish stock and enlarge his inventory of his general store

loan.name: Catarina

texts.en:
Catarina is a lively 25-year-old married women, with two children. Both her children go to school, the youngest to kindergarten.

Catarina grew up in Maputo, where she attended school until 6th grade. She stopped studying due to her familyâ€™s financial difficulties (they were 14 siblings and only some could attend school at the same time). In 1997 she met her husband, Paulo Miguel, who paid her tuition to attend 7th grade. Catarina got pregnant soon after, so she stopped studying again to take care of the house.

In 2005 Catarina started working as an assistant at a company in Maputo, and with their monthly income they were able to buy a house in the beautiful Matola neighborhood. In 2006, her father-in-law asked his son Paulo to take care of his driving school in Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland, so they moved there. In 2007 Catarina went back to school to complete 8th grade. However, as her father-in-law passed the property to his son, she was appointed to take care of the bar adjacent to the driving school.

Catarina makes around MTn 500 to MTn 1,500 per day at the bar. In addition she receives a rent of MTn6,000 from her house in Maputo. Catarina has one employee that helps her with the house duties, takes care of the boys and also works at the bar when necessary.

Both Catarina and Paulo are very business oriented. They realized that Namaacha district has no funeral service, nor a place to buy coffins. They have already a land near the cemetery where they are building a shop to sell coffins and other funeral items needed for services. As Paulo was already a Hluvuku client (he had a loan to buy a new car for the driverâ€™s school â€“ loan already concluded), Catarina decided to ask for this MTn 25,000 loan to buy the land where they will build the coffin manufacturing plant, just outside Namaacha village.

In the future, Catarina would like to go back to school. Her dream is to be a nurse or a doctor, so she still wants to go to university, no matter how long it takes.

loan.use: Buy land to build a coffin manufacturing plant

loan.name: Gadoufi

texts.en: Mr. Gadoufi D. is 40 years old and the married father of 4 children, 2 of whom are in school. He runs a small gas station in the center of AdÃ¨ta, a medium-sized town located about 150 kilometers from LomÃ©, the capital of Togo. He and his sister, who is a few years older than he, run the gas station together, as it is too busy for one person to work alone. The motorcycles that crowd AdÃ¨tas streets are always hungry for more of Gadoufiâ€™s gas, and with this loan, he hopes to purchase more gas and clean his pumps to satisfy his customers. As 2 of his children are too young to be in school, Gadoufi hopes to be able to save enough money through his business to enroll them in primary school when the time comes.

loan.use: To purchase more gas and clean existing gas pumps

loan.name: Desmond

texts.en: Mr. Desmond A. is a young man of 20 years with a strong entrepreneurial spirit. He is not yet married and does not have any children because he wants to first be able to provide for his future family. Desmond sells parts and tires for motorcycles, cars and farm equipment and has done very well for himself. A very motivated individual, he started his business when he was just 17 years old and has already received and paid back the largest loan in FECECAV AdÃ¨taâ€™s history. With this loan from Kiva, Desmond would like to continue growing his business by buying more parts to sell to his customers.

loan.use: To buy more parts and tires for motorcycles, cars and farm equipment

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Judite

texts.en:
Judite is 51- years-old and originally from Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland. She is married for the second time and has 3 children that live with her and go to school.

In 1976 she married for the first time, had 2 children, but got divorced in 1990 because her husband was beating her too much. In 1992 she married her second husband and had another child. Judite convinced her husband to buy a house in Namaacha and go back to the countryside. In 1994 they started raising chicken with an indemnity her husband received after getting fired.

In 1996, Judite was motivated by her friends to start working with plants, flowers and vases. She had a beautiful house and loved gardening, so her plants where extremely well cared for and attracted a lot of attention. Today she is one of the most well know gardeners of the district, selling to people living even in Maputo. She makes around MTn 10,000 per month with the sales of plants and flowers. She also does cement vases, but the business is more uncertain. Each vase is sold between MTn 500 and MTn 1,500, but mainly she produces under requests. Now she is doing 6 vases for the local Catholic Church, each at MTn 1,000. Judite has 5 permanent employees to help in the business.

After hearing about Hluvuku while chitchatting with a friend, she decided to ask for a loan of MTn 25,000 to expand the plant and flower business, and to buy more seeds and other products that are needed.

loan.use: Buy raw material for the flower business

loan.name: Akpene

texts.en: Ms. Akpene A. is 30 years old and the married mother of one child. Akpene owns a salon in AdÃ©ta, a medium-sized town located about 150 kilometers from LomÃ©, the capital of Togo. She specializes in â€˜tresses,â€™ a popular African hairstyle of braids made with synthetic hair. Akpene hopes to use this loan to buy another large mirror for the interior of her salon and also to invest in more hair products. With the revenue generated from her business, she will be able to improve the quality of life for her family and contine to send her child to school.

loan.use: To buy another mirror and hair products

loan.name: Adjo

texts.en: Ms. Adjo B. is 34 years old, single, and does not have any children. However, Adjo provides some much-needed help to her siblings by caring and providing for their numerous children. Adjo owns a salon just outside of the central market in AdÃ¨ta, a location that attracts the market traffic throughout the week and especially on the weekends. Like many hairdressers in Togo, she specializes in â€˜tresses,â€™ a popular African hairstyle of braids made with synthetic hair. With her loan Adjo would like to buy more hair products and tresses to satisfy her customers. With these purchases she hopes to increase her sales to be able to raise her quality of life and contribute to the expenses of her siblingsâ€™ children.

loan.use: To buy more hair products and tresses

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 25, 2008)

loan.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa is 40 years old and originally from the Inhambane Province. She has been a widow since 1994 and has 2 children: a 18-year-old boy that goes to teacherâ€™s professional school and a 16-year-old girl that is still in 9th grade at the secondary school.

Josefa studied until 6th grade in Inhambane, but due to limited places for 7th grade, she moved to Namaacha in 1985 to live with her older brother that was a teacher. Josefa was studying at night and working at an agriculture company during the day. One year later, she got pregnant, so she stopped studying. She then worked for 3 years producing clothes at a local company, but had to leave because she got pregnant again. That was Josefaâ€™s hardest period; she was selling vegetables at the local market and barely making any money.

In 1992 Josefa started cooking meals. She had a stand in the border (Namaacha borders Swaziland) and would cook meals daily. In 1999 the border was closed, and all the stands where taken and sent to a far away open market, that only opens twice a week (on Wednesdays and Saturdays). Since then life has been very difficult, as Josefa only works twice a week. Each meal as in the picture (chicken, tomatoâ€™s salad and the traditional â€œchimaâ€ made of corn) is sold for MTn 40 (around US$1.6). Josefa makes around MTn 200 to MTn 300 in profits for a day. Since she sells food on credit, it is difficult to know the actual amount of money she may receive n a day.

This is Josefaâ€™s first loan with Hluvuku. She intends to use the MTn 6,000 to buy a large amount of raw material (tomatoes, corn, chicken, oil and so on) so that she can stop asking for credit at other stands. This will help her make more profit at the end of the day. In the future, Josefa would like to build her own stand elsewhere, where she could work every day of the week and make even more money.

loan.use: Buy raw material: produce, meats and other necessities for the â€œrestaurant/foodâ€ stand

loan.name: Ernest

texts.en:
Ernest B. is a taxi driver who owns a taxi. He is married and has 4 dependents. He needs financial assistance to enable him to service his taxi.
He is asking for $325 as an additional fund to do some repair work on his taxi.

loan.use: As an additional fund to do some repair work on his taxi.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43702

loan.name: Ortense

texts.en: Ortense A. is 32 years old and the married mother of 3 children. Two of her children are enrolled in school and one works with her in her shop, which is located in the central market of AdÃ©ta, a medium-sized town about 150 kilometers away from LomÃ©, the capital of Togo. Popular dress in Togo consists of a skirt and top cut and tailored from lengths of fabric called pagnes, and another pagne wrapped around the waist. Selling pagnes is a popular business for women in Ortenseâ€™s region, so to stand out from her competition, Ortense decided to sell other miscellaneous items in her shop as well. With her loan, Ortense would like to travel to LomÃ© with her daughter to purchase more pagnes to resell in the market in AdÃ©ta. In addition, she would like to re-stock her supply of batteries, generic medication and soap. With the revenues from her shop, she hopes to be able to continue to take care of her family and send her children to school.

loan.use: To purchase more pagnes (West African fabrics) and supplies for her store.

loan.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma E. R. is 45 years old, a widow with 5 children - 3 minors and 2 adults. She is a native of Bluefields and sells diary products such as cheese, cream and milk curd. To do this, she travels every 10 days to the department of Chontales in Nicaragua, where these products are produced and then she delivers them to some of the general stores in the city. She has been doing this for more than 15 years and with her income has supported her five children. However, she has to purchase the products on short-term credit, which has not enabled her to develop her business. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy 300 pounds of cheese at US $0.90 per pound, 250 pounds of cream at US $.080 per pound and 100 units of curd at US $.090 per unit.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Vilma E. R. tiene 45 aÃ±os de edad, es viuda con 5 hijos tres menores de edad y 2 adultos, es originaria de Bluefields y se dedica a la venta de productos lacteos como queso, crema y cuajadas. Para tal fin viaja cada 10 dias a Chontales departamento de Nicaragua donde se producen estos productos y los entrega en algunas pulperias de esta ciudad. Esta seÃ±ora se dedica a este negocio desde hace mas de 15 aÃ±os y con sus ingresos a mantenido a sus cinco hijos. Sin embargo la compra de este producto lo obtiene al credito y en un lapso de tiempo corto por lo que no le a permitido desarrollarse como microempresaria. Esta solicitando un credito para poder comprar 300 libras de queso a US$ 0.90 dolares cada libra, 250 libras de crema a US$ 0.80 dolares cada libra y 100 cuajadas a US$ 0.90 cada unidad de cuajada.

loan.use: Buy 300 pounds of cheese, 250 pounds of cream and milk curd.

loan.name: Felicitas' Group

texts.es:
Celestina, Felicitas and Ana have belonged to the Communal Bank â€œLos Ladrilleros D. CompaÃ±Ã­aâ€ for a year.

Celestina is married, 48 years old and has 5 children, 2 of whom live with her. Felicitas is married, 59 years old and has 8 children, 4 of whom live with her. Meanwhile Ana is single and 22 years old.

Celestina, Felicitas and Ana are from the town called CompaÃ±Ã­a which is 40 minutes from the city of Ayucucho. They, along with their spouses, work making artesian bricks and they sell them in their city to distributors.

Celestina, Felicitas and Ana need loans of 900 soles, 300 soles, 2000 soles, to invest in the purchase of wood, coal, tools, and for the pay of the laborers.

The dreams of Celestina, Felicitas and Ana are that her children have work, expand her business, have a home in Ayacucho and help her mother, respectively.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Celestina, Felicitas y Ana pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Ladrilleros D. CompaÃ±Ã­a hace 1 aÃ±o.

Celestina es casada, tiene 48 aÃ±os y 5 hijos D. los cuales 2 viven con ella. Por otro lado Felicitas es casada, tiene 59 aÃ±os y 8 hijos, D. los cuales 4 viven con ella. Mientras que Ana es soltera y tiene 22 aÃ±os.

Celestina, Felicitas y Ana son D. la comunidad D. CompaÃ±Ã­a que esta a 40 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, ellas junto a sus esposos se dedican a la fabricaciÃ³n D. ladrillos artesanales y sus ventas lo realizan en su misma comunidad a intermediarios.

Celestina, Felicitas y Ana necesitan prÃ©stamos D. 900 soles, 300 soles, 2000 soles, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra D. leÃ±a, carbÃ³n, herramientas y para el pago D. los peones.

Los sueÃ±os D. Celestina, Felicitas y Ana son que sus hijos tengan trabajo, ampliar su negocio, tener una casa en Ayacucho y ayudar a su mamÃ¡.

loan.use: Celestina, Felicitas and Ana need loans of 900 soles, 300 soles, 2000 soles, respectively, to invest in the purchase of wood, coal, tools, and for the pay of the laborers.

loan.name: Lourdes 8 Group

texts.es:
Evangelina has a pharmacy in her home where she sells medical and personal care products. She began this business 7 years ago and with her loan she will invest in stocking up on medical and personal care items as the closest town to her is 30 minutes away. She is 38 years old and has three children. With her business she helps her husband with the household expenses. She belongs to the group called Lourdes 8 together with: Eluteria P. L. (who has a pharmacy) and Magdalena del Carmen M. P. (who has a bakery).

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

EVANGELINA TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA FARMACIA EN DONDE VENDE MEDICAMENTOS Y PRODUCTOS DE ASEO PERSONAL, INICIO ESTE NEGOCIO HACE SIETE AÃ‘OS Y CON SU PRESTAMO INVERTIRA EN EL SURTIDO DE MEDICAMENTOS Y DE ASEO PERSONAL YA QUE EL PUEBLO MAS CERCANO A SU LOCALIDAD ESTA A 30 MINUTOS. ELLA TIENE 38 AÃ‘OS Y TRES HIJOS, CON SU NEGOCIO APOYA A SU ESPOSO CON LOS GASTOS FAMILIARES. PERTENECE AL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO LOURDES 8, JUNTO CON: ELUTERIA P. L. (TIENE UNA FARMACIA) Y DOÃ‘A MAGDALENA DEL CARMEN M. P. (TIENE UNA PANADERIA).

loan.use: invest in the purchase of medical and personal care products

loan.name: Yolanda Del Rio Group

texts.es:
The Yolanda del RÃ­o Association of the Villa Adela Focus Center owes its name to the affection, respect and admiration that its 21 members have toward the woman responsible for said Center.

In its majority, its members find themselves obligated to peddle, offering their products through the biggest fairs and nearby markets due to the lack of permanent sales stands. New and used clothing, electric appliances, pastries and other products are sold in their small businesses that represent sustenance for their families, especially those that are married, since only about 10% of its members are single.

Currently, they need capital to invest in their businesses with the objective of generating the necessary resources to face the difficult situation their country is passing through, and with the sole purpose of sustaining their families.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La asociaciÃ³n Yolanda del RÃ­o del Centro Focal de Villa Adela, debe su nombre al cariÃ±o respeto y admiraciÃ³n que las 21 socias que componen la misma, le tienen a la responsable de dicho Centro. En su mayorÃ­a, las socias se ven obligadas a deambular ofertando sus productos, por las principales ferias y mercados de sus zonas a raÃ­z de la carencia de puestos de venta fijos. Ropa nueva y usada, electrodomÃ©sticos, reposterÃ­a y otros, son pequeÃ±os negocios que les representa el sustento para sus familias, principalmente aquellas que son casadas, ya que de todo el grupo solo un 10% son solteras. Actualmente ellas precisan de capital para invertir en sus negocios, con el objetivo de generar los recursos suficientes para hacer frente a la difÃ­cil situaciÃ³n que atraviesa el paÃ­s, con el Ãºnico objetivo de sustentar a sus familias.

loan.use: Purchase capital to invest in their respective businesses.
