loan.use: Invest in various businesses

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia T., 20, is married to a farmer. She is entering the business of selling taro. Both she and her husband will do the farming. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, 2 filings, seeds, pumpkins, and fertilizer.

loan.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, etc.

loan.name: Saasaai 2 Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
For these 3 women of Saasaai 2 on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Aussie F., 18, is married with 1 child. She is starting a bakery business. With her loan, she will purchase cement, metal, and iron roofing to construct an oven. Also, she will purchase oil, flour, sugar, and other ingredients to make pies, biscuits, buns, and other baked goods.

Asolelei T., 39, is married with 7 children. She grows taro, yams, bananas, and other vegetable and fruit produce. Although her family has been doing it for many years, this is her first business selling produce. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a filing, 2 bow knives, and fertilizer.

Teuila L., 46, is married with 11 children. Her sons help her farm her taro and yam plantation. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, cabbage seeds, and a license. She will sell her produce 5 days per week.

loan.use: Purchase supplies to start a bakery and for farming

loan.name: Fusi Safotulafai Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 7 women of Fusi Safotulafai mupapa on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business, maintaining a savings account and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

See K. (49, married, 3 children) will purchase fertilizer, pesticides, a weed killer, a bush knife, and a knife filing for her taro business.

Palota F. (41, married, 3 children) will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, a knife filing, a spade, and an axe for her taro business.

Pelo P. (53, divorced, 3 children) will purchase flour, sugar, oil, yeast, a deep fryer, and gas to cook pancakes for sale.

Silivia K. (49, married, 4 children) will purchase a fishing net, a torch, goggles, a spear, and bait for her fishing business.

Pipiana P. (32, married, 1 child) will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, and a bush knife for her taro business.

Faasu F. (20, married, 1 child) will purchase a weed killer, fertilizer, pesticides, a bush knife, a filing, and an axe.

Irene I. (30, married, 2 children) will purchase a weed killer, fertilizer, pesticides, a bush knife and a filing.

loan.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, etc

loan.name: Faamita

texts.en: Faamita M., 32, is married with 3 children. She has over 2 years of experience selling baked goods and growing vegetables. She wishes to buy supplies to expand both of her businesses. Specifically, she will purchase flour, sugar, oil, yeast, pesticides, and a weed killing sprayer.

loan.use: Purchase a weed killer and pesticides

loan.name: Saletagaloa Salelologa Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 11 women of Saletagaloa Salelologa on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Faaiviivi F. (54, married, 5 children) to purchase a spade, pesticides, knives, a planting stick, a filing, and a wheelbarrow for her fruit and vegetable (taro, yam, cocoa, bananas and other produce) business.

Luisa I. (43, married, 5 children) to purchase chemicals, knives, weed killer, a sack of sugar, plastic, and concentrate for her vegetable (taro and banana) and ice cake (ice cream) businesses.

Nive F. S. (21, married, 1 child) to purchase chicken legs, corned beef, fish, spam, noodles, sugar, rice cheese, gel, tea, and other items for her retail shop.

Ana E. (52, married, 8 children) to purchase pesticides, a knife and a wheel barrow for her fruit and vegetable (taro, bananas, cucumbers, pumpkins and tomatoes) business.

Tusiga T. (54, married) to purchase a fishing net, a hook and a spear for her fish business.

Malie S. (42, divorced, 6 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, and a knife filing.

Pelita F. (62, married, 9 children) to purchase pesticides, fertilizer, a wheel barrow, seeds, and a bush knife for her fruit and vegetable (cabbages, tomatoes, cucumbers) business.

Mema Tautua (50, married, 6 children) to purchase fertilizer, a filing, a knife, pesticides, and a fishing net for her taro and fish businesses.

Lulu T. (34, married, 4 children) to purchase an elei board, x-ray designs, brushes, threads, material, paints and shelves for her clothing business.

Rosa F. P. (28, married, 2 children) to purchase barbed wires, rice, nails, hammer, and knives to raise chicken chickens and make handbags.

Siutu L. (21, married, 3 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, planting stick, a knife, a filing, and a spade.

loan.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, etc

loan.name: Fatma's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 40 years old and is a widow with 2 children, ages 25 and 22 years old. Fatma has been selling charcoal and fish since 2007. Every day, she works from 4m to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Salelologa Sapulu Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 8 women of Salelologa Sapulu on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Faimafili M. (44, married, 11 children) to purchase a fishing boat, a fishing net, goggles, and a spear for her fish business.

Iutita S. (28, married) to purchase a sewing machine for her clothing business.

Eseta S. (29, married, 2 children) to purchase a cooler, a box of cups, pesticides, a bag of sugar, and candy for her ice cake (ice cream) business.

Alofa T. M. (30, married, 3 children) to purchase timber, iron roofing, and cement to build her barber shop.

Sialia T. F. (59, married, 4 children) to purchase oil, a gas oven, large pots, and plastic cups for her popcorn and clothing businesses.

Fualole A. (26, married, 1 child) to purchase concentrate, sugar, plastic cups, candy, and a cooler for her ice cake business.

Faoliu M S. (43, single, 2 children) to purchase an oven, flour, sugar, pork, and other items for her pork and bread business.

Panou M. (47, married, 5 children) to purchase sugar, flour, butter, eggs, yeast, and cement and timber to build her bakery which sells donuts, pork cakes and bread.

loan.use: Purchase supplies for fishing, sewing, and other businesses

loan.name: Asha's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Asha is 22 years old and is a single woman. Asha owns a small tailoring shop, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Chuob

texts.en:
Chuob T., age 47, lives with her husband and eight children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has a business selling groceries and earns around $1.5 a day of profit. Her husband, Sao Cheo, 48, is a construction worker building a house. He makes around $1 of profit per day. One son is a construction worker like his father and earns around $1.5 a day and two of their daughters are employed as garment factory workers with a salary of $70 each per month. The rest of their children are students.

To make the family's standard of living better and reduce the cost of commuting to work, Chuob T. would like to take a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to commute to work.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her daughters for commute to work

loan.name: Tafua Tai Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 6 women of Tafua Tai on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Saloaloa M. (58, married, 8 children) to purchase tools, mats, and other materials to create handicrafts.

Afiafi L. (58, single, 2 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, taro roots, laborers, 2 knives, and BBQ supplies for her BBQ and produce (taro, bananas, etc) businesses.

Potoae L. (62, widow, 4 children) to pay for a wheelbarrow, laborers, knives, a filing, and other items for her produce (yam, taro, banana, coconut, etc) business.

Sui L. (31, married, 1 child) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 knives, a knife filing, an axe, laborers, and taro roots for her produce (taro, yam, and banana) business.

Faaiulotu F. (44, widow, 6 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a knife, and taro roots for her produce (taro, yam, bananas, etc) business.

Elisapeta M. (26, married, 1 child) to purchase an elei board, brushes, materials and pains for her Elei painted sarongs, dresses and t-shirts.

loan.use: Purchase tools to make handicrafts and farming

loan.name: Moli's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Moli is 34 years old and is divorced with 2 children, ages 13 and 7 years old. Moli has been selling fish since 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Moli now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loan.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach K., age 29, is a young mother of three children and has lived in Kampong Cham province for many years. She works making Khmer cake and has been selling them at the market since 2006, normally earning around $1.5 a day of profit. Her husband works making cutting boards. In Cambodia, usually all the cutting boards are made from wood. He receives $4 a day for his work. To make more profits, the couple would like to take a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike and trailer to run a new business. This will give them extra income to support the household. (Picture is of husband and wife.)

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike and trailer

loan.name: Kazija's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Kazija is 38 years old and is married with 7 children, ages 12 to 20 years old. Kazija has been a food supplier since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Kazija now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loan.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is 44 years old and is divorced with 4 children, ages 24, 22, 20 and 14 years old. She also takes care of 4 other children, ages 1-6 years old. Salma sells mobiles, perfumes, clothes and shoes starting in 1992. Everyday, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items (mobiles, perfumes, clothes and shoes) for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Try

texts.en: Mrs. Try M., age 42, is married with six children and resides in Kampong Cham province with her husband of many years. She and her husband, Ek Sam Eoeun, 44, work to raise the familyâ€™s income by making cutting boards and selling them to the market to earn approximately $2.5 of profit per day. One child is a construction worker building a house and makes about $2 a day. This couple would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase cashew nuts to stock and resell for profit.

loan.use: To purchase cashew nuts to stock

loan.name: Asha's Hatuchoki Group

texts.en:
Asha is 37 years old and is divorced with 3 children, ages 17, 14, and 3 years old. She also takes care of 2 other children, ages 26 and 20 years old. Asha began her business in 1998; today she conducts a mobile phone business and also sells soup. Every day, she works from 7am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a small business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other member is responsible.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 34 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 9 months to 12 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, who is 56 years old. Mwajuma owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Mwajuma now hopes for a loan to buy charcoal for her business.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loan.name: Siti

texts.id:
Mrs. Siti A. is a food vendor. She sells mixed rice (fast food). Her food stall is located at Kupaon street, which is one of the main street in Bali as it is the main intersection for tourist hot spots such as Sanur, Kuta and Nusa Dua. She lives with her husband in a rented room.

She wakes up at 04.00 am everyday to start her food business. Her customers mainly are travelers at Kupaon street and also her neighbors. The money she earns is used to pay for the rent and also to help her to make end's meet.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Jl.Kupaon merupakan jalur yang sangat ramai karena merupakan jalur penghubung antara Denpasar dan daerah pariwisata seperti Sanur, Kuta dan Nusa Dua. Usaha warung yang digeluti Ibu Siti A. cukup lancar meskipun setiap hari dia harus bangun jam 04.00 pagi untuk belanja kebutuhan warung, Ibu Siti A. tetap semangat karena dibantu oleh suaminya, Adapun pembelinya adalah mereka yang lewat sekitar Jl.Kupaon dan juga tetangga sekitar. keuntungan yang didapat dari hasil usaha warung cukup untuk dipergunakan untuk membayar sewa kamar kost dan juga memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya.

loan.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Eith

texts.en: Mrs. Eith M., age 39, lives with her younger sister and works raising pigs at her house. She earns $3.5 a day. Her younger sister, Eith Me, age 30, owns a plot of farmland growing rice, making about $1 a day. These two sisters are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more pigs, food for the pigs, and fertilizers to put on the farmland. Moreover, any extra from the loan will be used to build a stable house.

loan.use: To purchase more pigs, food for the pigs, and fertilizers to put on the farmland

loan.name: Bou

texts.en: Bou S. is 50 years old and owns a small farm in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband have grown vegetables to sell in the market since 1980. They support themselves and their only child on a combined daily income of US $3. Their daughter also works at a local garment factory making US $50 per month. They want to invest in an additional plot of farmland on which to grow vegetables, which will bring them greater financial security.

loan.use: To buy farmland

loan.name: Fatma's Jiimarishe Group

texts.en:
Fatma S. is 35 years old and is divorced woman with 3 children, ages 12,8 and 2 years old. Fatma S. conduct a small business of making and selling chapatis, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her chapati business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more chapatis for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Fatma Y.. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other member is responsible.

loan.use: To buy more food items to make chapatis

loan.name: Hafsa

texts.en:
Hafsa is 36 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 22,15,12 and 6 years old. Hafsa has a small business of selling sarongs that she started in 2005. Every day, she sells sarongs from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Hafsa has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her sarong business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more sarongs to sell

loan.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin S. is a 38 year old rice farmer in the province of Kampong Cham. She earns less than US $1 per day farming. Her husband, Sek Chea, does a little bit better as an ice cream vendor in Siem Reap province earning US $5 per day. Of their three children, one is currently employed as a security guard making US $30 monthly. She wants to take out a loan to buy the necessary wood to fix her family home, which they can't afford on their regular income. They also hope to save some money to someday buy Sek Chea a motorbike, which he can use to make his business mobile.

loan.use: To renovate their home

loan.name: Im

texts.en: Im M. is 44 years of age and has been farming rice since 1998. She makes approximately US $1.60 per day. Her husband raises pigs earning US $1 daily. They have had seven children together, only one of whom is married. One of the older children helps the family by collecting juice from sugar palm trees to be refined into local wine. He adds US $2 per day to the family income. Two others help their father with the pigs. With her loan, Im M. hopes to buy more pigs for her husband to breed. She also wants to invest in a small grinding mill for food production that she can also rent out to her neighbors.

loan.use: To buy pigs and a grinding mill

loan.name: Mwanahamis's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Mwanahamis is 28 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 4 years old. Mwanahamis has a small business of making and selling chapatis that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanahamis has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her chapati business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as flour, sugar, and oil for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Asha, Rehema and Nyeshi, who also have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more food items in order to make more chapatis

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: San

texts.en: San S. is 63 years old and runs a small grocery store out of her home in Kampong Cham province. Her husband, Man Chim, works with her in their store. They earn on average US $7.20 per day. Both of their children are grown up and living outside of the family home. She wants to buy groceries in bulk because she feels that expanding her inventory will attract more business as time goes on.

loan.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loan.name: Asha's Jitihad Group

texts.en:
Asha is 32 years old and is married. Asha started her small charcoal business in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm selling charcoal and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Asha has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Zainabu, Mkasi, and Maulid, who also have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loan.name: Saumu's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Saumu is 25 years old and is married. Saumu conducts a small donut business that she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm making and selling donuts at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Saumu now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to increase her production of donuts. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mariam and Mwanaisha, who have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Suis

texts.id:
Mrs. Suis M. starts her electrical store in 2002. She sells various electrical supplies such as lamp, cable, electrical plug etc from major suppliers who deliver the goods to her store. She also sometimes buy her merchandise from another major/ bigger store at Denpasar. Her store is located at Kupaon street, one of the busiest street in Denpasar.

She uses the money she earn from this store to expand her business and also to improve her family's well being.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Ibu Suis M. mulai menjalankan usaha jual alat-alat listrik sejak tahun 2002. Alat-alat listrik yang dijual seperti lampu, kabel, stop kontak yang ia beli dari supplier yang mengantarnya langsung, dan juga ia membeli dari seputaran Kota Denpasar dan dijual di daerah Kupaon. Karena letaknya strategis dan berada ditempat yang padat penduduknya, usahanya begitu ramai dan banyak pengunjung atau pembeli yang ketokonya. Dari keuntungannya ia bisa pakai sebagai tambahan usaha dan untuk keperluan rumah tangganya.

loan.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Ziada's Hatuyumbi Group

texts.en:
Ziada A. is 31 years old and is married. Ziada started her business of selling sarongs and bread in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.
Ziada has taken and repaid one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for another loan to buy more sarongs and bread to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more bread and sarongs to sell

loan.name: Sada's Safinia Group

texts.en:
Sada is a married woman. She started her business of making and selling chapatis in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

In the past, Sada has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more chapatis for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in small business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more food items to make chapatis

loan.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang D., 50, lives with his wife and two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. He grows rice and vegetables to earn around $5 a day. His wife, Sovann, is a local doctor. She makes $1 a day. Their children are students. This couple wants to borrow from Kiva to purchase more farmland to grow more rice in order to receive more output.

loan.use: To purchase wood to install in the house (repair work)

loan.name: Salama's Safinia Group

texts.en:
Salama is 41 years old and is married with 6 children, ages 5-29 years old. Salama started her business in 2008. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $33 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zahra, who has business dealing in small business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Rodiyah

texts.id:
Rodiyah has been in the business of selling mixed rice for around 3.5 years by now. She buys her mixed rice's ingredients from Sanglah market which is located near by her house. She goes to the market at 04.00 am everyday and she starts to cook at 05.00 am. Her customers are travelers who pass by her food stall at Satelit Street and also her surrounding neighbors.

She wants to use the loan money to expand her food stall business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha jualan nasi campur sudah dimulai olehIbu Rodiyah sekitar 3,5 tahun yang lalu. Ibu Rodiyah biasanya belanja bahan-bahan kebutuhan warungnya di Pasar Sanglah yang jaraknya tidak jauh dari rumahnya. Ia berangkat pukul 04.00 ke pasar dan pukul 05.00 ia sudah mulai memasak. Para konsumennya adalah mereka yang lewat sekitar Jl. Satelit dan orang-orang yang kost disekitar wilayah itu. Pinjaman kali ini rencananya akan dipergunakan sebagai penunjang modal usahanya mengembangkan warung nasi campur..

loan.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Lipi

texts.en:
Lipi is 42 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 21,12, and 9 years old. Lipi started her small juice and chapati business in 2008. Every day, she makes and sell these items from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more juice and chapatis. She is a member of a loan group, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loan.use: To buy more food items to make juice and chapatis

loan.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina O. lives in Ilogbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a married woman with 8 children and she sells textbooks and greeting cards. Sabina acquired this skill in 1 month and has been in her business since 1988. At 46 years of age, she wants to diversify her business to sell office accessories, like staplers and perferators, in addition to her textbooks and greeting cards. She needs a loan of $600 to enable her to buy more textbooks and office accessories to see. She says "thank you."

loan.use: To buy more books and office accessories.

loan.name: Mosi's Heri Yetu Group

texts.en:
Mosi is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,12, and 8 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 76 years old. Mosi has a small business that she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $33 from her sales.

In the past, Mosi has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Mgeni's Heri Yetu Group

texts.en:
Mgeni is 39 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 16,12,8 and 5 years old. Mgeni is a business woman. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $23 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Nadra,Khadija and Bimkubwa, all of whom have small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Hidaya's Hatutaki Matatizo Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 39 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 10 years old. Hidaya is a business woman. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Hidaya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma, Chema and Mtumwa, who have small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her busienss.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Hidaya's Hatutaki Matatizo Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 39 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 10 years old. hidaya is a business woman, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Hidaya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma, Chema and Mtumwa, who have businesses dealing in small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her busienss.

loan.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia U. sells clothes and tailoring materials.She has been in this business for the past 6 years. She lives in Iyanuera in Lagos State, Nigeria.She is 27 years of age with 2 children, and has being borrowing from LAPO microfinance for the past 2 years.

Felicia needs a loan of $875 to enable her buy more clothes and tailoring material in order to expand her business. She is thankful to Kiva for this opportunity. This can be seen from the broad smile in her face throughout our interview.

loan.use: To buy more cloths and tailoring materials.

loan.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana E. is a married woman. She is 25 years old. She sells provisions, drinks and cosmetics, and she has been in this business for the past 5 years. She hails from Igbede, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Christiana needs a loan of $600 to enable her buy more provisions, cosmetics and drinks to sell. With this loan, she said her business will be positioned for greater performance. She thanks you.

loan.use: To buy more provisions and cosmetics.

loan.name: Hadija's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Hadiaj is 43 years old and is a married woman with 6 children, ages 8-29 years old. Hadija has a small business. She started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

In the past, Hadija has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwandawa, who has a small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero L.â€™s business has of two categories: she sells fish and gently used clothing. At 44 years of age with 5 children, she still has enough energy to sell fish in the evening after returning from the market where she sells used clothes. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years and hails from Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs a loan of $600 to enable her buy more fish and used clothes to sell.

loan.use: To buy more dry fish and used clothes

loan.name: Mariam's Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Mariam, age 38, is married with four children, ages 17, 12, and 6 year-old twins. She has a charcoal-selling business which she started in 2005. She works from 7 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. daily, and makes a profit of about $55 a month from her sales.

In the past, Mariam took out a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more charcoal to sell. She repaid it, and now hopes for a new loan which she will use for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her group, whose members run businesses in which they sell items such as drinks, fruits and vegetables, and provide tailoring services.

In the picture, Mariam is in yellow on the right.

loan.use: To help several small businesses expand

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Bbogo Women's Group

texts.en:
Bbogo is a small village in Lugazi where the soil is very fertile. N. Dezi, the chairperson of Bbogo Womenâ€™s Group, has taken advantage of that fertility by raising bananas known locally as matooke, potatoes and maize on her family's land. She also prepares a local brew known as waragi for sale using a certain kind of banana that grows on her farm. She also buys these bananas from other farmers, since demand for the beverage is extremely high, especially among fishermen.

Dezi is 42 years old, married and has 10 children, six girls and four boys. She chairs a loan group that has been together for 10 years. All of the group's members agree that before loans were available, life was hard and if your business encountered problems, that was the end. Now, one can get a loan and invest in other businesses while growing your own and helping it through hard times. Because this is possible, local people can now send their children to school.

Dezi has applied for a new loan to expand her businesses by buying more bananas and a drum in which to make waragi, as well hire workers for her farm who can help her prepare to plant new crops. The other members of this group will use their portions of this loan to expand their own small businesses.

loan.use: To help several small businesses grow

loan.name: Yi

texts.en: Yi L. is 42 years old and lives in Siem Reap. She makes her living selling fish in the local market. Her business does relatively well, bringing in US $8 per day. Her husband works as a motor taxi driver based in front of a local hospital. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. The remaining four are all enrolled in school. She wants to expand her market-standâ€™s inventory by buying more expensive kinds of fish. She hopes this will make her business more competitive.

loan.use: To buy fish

loan.name: Siti's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Siti is 45 years old and is a widow with 6 children, ages 12-20 years old. Siti is a business woman. She started in 1978. Every day, she works from 7am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $200 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Sekinut

texts.en:
Sekinut A. is 35 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her business is not too common in her community where she lives; she sells plywood and packing case wood. She hails from Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 1998.

Sekinut has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years and she is requesting a loan of $875 to enable her buy more plywood and packing case wood to sell.

loan.use: To buy more of plywood and packing case wood

loan.name: Sudi's Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Sudi, age 52, is married and has five children, ages 30, 25, 20, 18 and 16. He owns a stationary shop where he sells office supplies. He started this business in 2006, and works there from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily. Each month, the shop brings in about $380 in profit.

In the past, Sudi has taken out four loans to buy more stock for his shop. He paid these loans back, and now has applied for a new loan to open a small general store. He will share the loan with his group, whose members have businesses in which they sell chips, vegetables, beverages, food and other items.

In the picture, Sudi is standing in the back row, wearing a white shirt.

loan.use: To open a small general store and support other small businesses

loan.name: Asha's Sitaki Shari Group

texts.en:
Asha is 35 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 12-20 years old. Asha has a small business. She started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Viwe, who has a small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanjuma is 47 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 25,24,23 and 20 years. Mwanajuma is a business woman. She started in 1998. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Folake

texts.en:
Folake Y. is a wholesale distributor of charcoal. She buys her charcoal from Ogun State Market. She makes the three-hour journey by car four times each month. She lives in Ajangbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria.

She acquired the skill of trading in 1Â½ years and has been in her business since 2001. She needs of a loan of $875 to buy more charcoal to sell.

loan.use: To buy more charcoal

loan.name: Mosumola

texts.en: Mosumola L. sells notebooks, textbooks, and greeting cards in her bookshop not too far from Iyano â€“ Ajangbandi community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 48 years old with 4 children, two of whom assist her in the shop. She acquired her skill in a year and has been in this business since 2003. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more books and textbooks to sell. She says "thank you!"

loan.use: To buy more notebooks & textbooks for sale.

loan.name: Rath

texts.en: Rath S. is 35 years old and makes her living selling vegetables from her home. She earns US $5 per day in this business. Her husband, Hen Saroeut, is a construction foreman for their local village earning US $3 per day. Together they have three young children. She wants to take out a loan so she can afford to fix her home as it is also her storefront. With any left over money she will purchase vegetables in bulk.

loan.use: To buy more vegetables and fix the house

loan.name: Tweeweeyo Women's Group

texts.en:
Barbara K. is the chairperson of Tweweeyo Womenâ€™s Group, which is located in the Lweru trading center. This group has been together for eight years. Kagoyais operates a beauty parlor in Lweru called the Nalongo Beauty Salon. It has operated successfully for eight years, and specializes in braiding, weaving and perming hair using weaves, braids and hair creams such as Ultra sheen, Venus and Movit that she gets in Lugazi Town.

Barbara is 37 years old and married with seven children, six of whom are in school. Her youngest child is still breastfeeding. Her husband works at a nearby business, and together they earn enough money to run their home and pay school fees for their children. She is thankful for the loans she has received in the past, and has now applied for a new loan through Kiva because she has heard other people talk favorably about it and believes it is a great opportunity for the group.

loan.use: To buy supplies for a beauty parlor and help several other small businesses

loan.name: Kulwa's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Kulwa M. is 58 years old, married and has two children, ages 21 and 19. He runs a furniture store which he opened six years ago. He works from 7:30 a.m to 6 p.m. daily, and makes a profit of about $424 a month.

In the past, Kulwa has taken out four loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of furniture he has to sell. He has applied for a new loan for the same purpose. Kulwa will share this loan with the members of his group, who sell items such as fruit and vegetables, and services such as carpentry, butchery and grooming.

In the photo, Kulwa is second from the left in the back row, wearing a white shirt.

loan.use: To help several small businesses expand

loan.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm N. is 28 years old. She works in a hotel in Siem Reap earning US $4 per day. Run Sophal, her husband (pictured here as she was unavailable), works as a motor taxi driver earning US $4 per day. They have two young children who are not yet old enough for school. She wants to build a well by their home so that she can run a small business pumping and selling water in her neighborhood.

loan.use: To dig a new well

loan.name: Jema

texts.en: Jema is a married woman with 2 children, ages 22 and 18 years old. Jema owns a small shop. She started in 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $9 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Khadija's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Khadija is 44 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 24,17,13 and 9 years old. Khadija is a business woman. She started in 1993. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Fatma, who has a small business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is 29 years old, married and has a three-year-old son. She runs a beauty salon and a shop. She started these businesses a year ago, and works from 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. managing them. The salon brings her a monthly profit of about $35, and the shop brings in about $280.

In the past, Paulina used a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy products for her beauty salon. Having paid this loan back successfully, she has applied a new loan to buy more products for her shop.

Paulina belongs to a loan group known as Umoja, whose 22 members ensure that the loans they take out will be repaid.

loan.use: To buy more items to sell from her shop

loan.name: Nsubuga's Group

texts.en:
Fred, Bena, Twaha and Zabina are members of the Tweweeyo Womenâ€™s Group, which is located in the Lweru trading center. They have applied for a group loan which will allow all of them to expand their businesses.

Fred sells yellow bananas to retailers and traders, and would like to buy more produce from farmers to sell to his clients. Bena sells local brews known as waragi and malwa, and would like to buy more sorghum and pots to make his work easier. Twaha deals in scrap, which he buys from the surrounding villages and sells to steel plants. He will use his loan to buy more materials to sell. Zabina has a six-year-old restaurant in Lweru, and needs a loan to buy more plates, spoons, saucepans and charcoal for cooking food.

loan.use: To help four small businesses expand

loan.name: Bikwao

texts.en:
Bikwao is 48 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,16 and 5 years old. Bikwao has a small business. She started in 1988. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Bikwao has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Sek Chan

texts.en: Sek Chan N. is 46 years old and lives in Siem Reap. She is a housewife while her husband works at a night club along with their eldest son. Her husband, Tuong Phan, earns US $6 per day. They want to secure their family's future by building a better home from which to possibly run a business in the future.

loan.use: To build a house

loan.name: Fatuma's Chimbuko Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 51, is married and has four children, ages 21, 19, 17 and 4 . For the past six years, she has made a living selling cosmetics and food. She works from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily, and makes a monthly profit of around $26.

In the past, Fatuma took out two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to start her businesses. Now she has applied for a new loan to increase her capital and expand these businesses. Fatuma will share this loan with the Chimbuko group, which has 15 members. These members will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. They run a variety of businesses which sell food, soft drinks and beer, oil, clothing, charcoal and other items.

In the picture, Fatuma is second from the left in a blue dress.

loan.use: To buy more food items and cosmetics

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en:
While visiting Victoria E. in Abulaka Community, Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria, we learned that she has been a widow for the past 10 years. Life has not been easy for her, but she manages her small business where she sells groceries, drinks and food. She has acquired her business skills over many years. She is now 51 years of age and has six children. She has been in business since 1988.

Victoria is requesting a loan of $875 to buy more groceries, food, and drinks to sell.

loan.use: To buy more Provisions, foodstuff & drinks for sale

loan.name: Abiodun

texts.en:
L. Abiodun sells notebooks and textbooks where she lives in Ajagbandi Community, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 33 years old, married, and has 2 children. She acquired the skill of trading in 4 years and has been operating this business since 1999.

She is requesting a loan of $1,025 to buy more textbooks and notebooks to sell. She is dedicated to her business.

loan.use: To buy more books and textbooks to sell

loan.name: Nghan

texts.en: Nghan S. is a 45 year old housewife living in Siem Reap. Her husband, Tan Sokhorn is 65 years old and is a local carpenter. He earns US $5 per day to support his wife and their two children. She wants to purchase a better set of carpentry tools for him to keep up with changing technology and protect their family's source of income.

loan.use: To buy better tools

loan.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Chhorn S. is 28 years old and lives in Siem Reap province. She sells souvenirs to tourists by the famous Angkor temples around which her city has grown. She earns US $5 per day through her business. Her husband is a musician who runs a small shop selling traditional Cambodian instruments to tourists. They have two children who are not old enough to be in school. She wants to expand her inventory by ordering more souvenir products to meet the growing customer demand.

loan.use: To buy souvenirs for resale

loan.name: Maarufu's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
M. M. is 32 years old, married and has two children, who are 10 and 3 years old. For the past six years, he has made a living selling secondhand clothing. He works from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily, and is able to make a monthly profit of about $254.

M. has applied for a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of clothing he has for sale. He will share this loan with his group members, and they will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, M. is in the back row, second from the left.

loan.use: To buy more secondhand clothing to sell

loan.name: Juliet

texts.en:
The beautiful color display in Juliet O.â€™s shop makes her shop stand out from other shops in the locality. Her wares range from clothes, to handbags and jewelry. Juliet is a single woman and she is 29 years of age. Her aim is to improve her business, which will, in turn, increase her profit. She lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 1999.

Juliet needs a loan of $875 to buy more shoes, clothes and bags to sell. She thanks you.

loan.use: To buy more clothes, bags and shoes

loan.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Mrs Toyin A. is a struggling woman who lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. At 39 years of age with 4 children, she is the breadwinner of her family. She is trying her best to sell her frozen foods (turkey, chicken and fish) with just a deep freezer in the center of a local market in her community.

She acquired the skill of trading in 2 years, and has been in her business since 1993. Toyin is requesting a loan of $875 to buy a deep freezer and more frozen food so that she can increase the prosperity of her business.

loan.use: To buy more frozen food (chicken,turkey and fish)

loan.name: Salamotu

texts.en: Mrs. Salamotu M. has been a faithful client of LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years. She is 36 years old and has 3 children. She sells groceries in cartons (wholesale). She hails from Ajambgadi, Lagos State, Nigeria and has being in business since 1999. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more groceries to sell.

loan.use: To buy more provision for sale.

loan.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy O. lives in Shibiri, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells shoes, clothes and bags, a skill that she acquired in a year. She has been in business since 2005. Joy is 32 years old, married, and has 4 children. She is determined to support her husband, who earns a meager salary, in improving the prosperity of the family.

She is asking for a loan of $875 to buy more shoes, clothes and bags. She thanks you.

loan.use: To buy more shoes, clothes and bags for sale.

loan.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Oeun M. and his wife have been married since 1979. They have five children; one son and four daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. The other three children work in a garment factory. The family lives along the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mr. Oeun runs business in water supply distribution in the village. He has been doing this business for thirteen years. His wife has been a silk weaver for two years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells the them in Phnom Penh.
He is requesting a loan in the amount of $800 to purchase a water pipeline and water pumping machine to run a business in water supply distribution.

loan.use: to purchase a water pipeline and water pumping machine to run a business in water supply distribution

loan.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom D. and her husband married in 1997. They have no children. They live on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Sreymom has been a weaver since 1990. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village who will then sell them in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a policeman who operates a motor taxi in his spare time.
She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loan.use: to purchase materials to weave silk

loan.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat O. is a widow with eight children; one son and seven daughters. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home. Four of her children work in a garment factory, two weave silk at home and the youngest one studies at university. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers frO. PhnO. Penh.
Mrs. Yat has been a weaver since 1979. Itâ€™s a skill she learned frO. her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells them in PhnO. Penh.
She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase material for weaving silk and pay school fees for her son.

loan.use: to purchase materials to weave silk and pay school fees for her son

loan.name: Beauty

texts.en: Mrs. Beauty A. sells groceries in Ilogbo Community, not too far from Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 32 years of age, married, and has 2 children. She acquired the skill of trading many years ago and has been in business since 2004. Beauty needs a loan of $600 to buy more groceries to sell.

loan.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loan.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget U. is a typical business woman. She sells bread in Ireke Community, Lagos State, Nigeria. She was botn there and lives there even now. Bridget acquired her business skills many years ago and has been in this business since1988. At 53 years of age, with 8 children, she still has the energy needed for business. According to her, selling bread is the only skill she has acquired and, she treasures it. She is requesting a loan of $700 to buy more bread to sell.

loan.use: To buy more bread to sell

loan.name: Ahazi's Tarangire Group

texts.en:
Ahazi, age 64, is married and has 11 children. He started a furniture business in 1978, and works there from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. From this business, he makes about $480 a month.

In the past, Ahazi used a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand his business. Having successfully paid back this loan, he has applied for a new one to continue this expansion. He will share this loan with his group, whose members are in the chicken- and charcoal-selling businesses.

loan.use: To buy more stock for his furniture business

loan.name: Ngot

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngot V. is a widow with four children; three sons and one daughter. Two of her children are married and live outside the family home. Of her other two children, one weaves silk at home and the youngest one is a construction worker. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Ngot has been a weaver for forty one years. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will sell them in Phnom Penh.
She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loan.use: To purchase materials for weaving silk

loan.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhem S. is a widow with three children; two sons and one daughter. Two of her sons are married and live outside the family house. Her daughter is in school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Nhem has been a weaver for thirty five years. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will sell them in Phnom Penh.
She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loan.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk

loan.name: Chinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chinda Chok and her husband married in 2002. They have two sons. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Mrs. Chinda has been a silk weaver for fifteen years. Itâ€™s a skill she learned from her relative. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will then sell it in Phnom Penh.
Her husband works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband for work purposes.

loan.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband for work purposes

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria O. sells food in a local market in her community. She hails from Volk, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 36 years of age, married, and has 4 children. She has been in business since 2006. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more food to sell. She said this will help her to serve her customers better.

loan.use: To buy more food to sell

loan.name: Olaide

texts.en: Mrs. Olaide Shorinola hails from Ikundo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sell groceries in her area. Although she did not undergo any training for her business, she is vocal and business-oriented. She is 45 years of age with 4 children and has been in business since 2005. Olaide needs a loan of $875 to to buy more groceries to sell.

loan.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loan.name: Velida

texts.en: Velida was born in 1980 and she is married. Her husband has a full time job and his monthly income is 900,00KM. They have two children. Velida wants to use this loan of 800,00KM ($650 USD) to buy food for her livestock in order to improve her business. She breeds cows and sells milk products.

loan.use: For buying food for livestock.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Anitha's Muungano Middle Group

texts.en:
Anitha is 24 years old and is married woman with a 6-year-old child. Anitha owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mariam and Mwanahamisi, who have small businesses.

loan.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Groupment Dagan

texts.en:
Groupement Dagan is a business created by 5 women in AdÃ©ta, Togo, a medium-sized town located aproximately 150 kilometers from the capital. The group is composed of Philomene A., the manager, a 38-year-old married woman; Louise A., a 26-year-old married woman; her sister Mofemo A., a 28-year-old married woman; Abra T., a 37-year-old married woman; and Marie M., a 31-year-old woman who is not yet married.

This close-knit group of family and friends sell a variety of prepared food in the central market of AdÃ©ta in order to earn a living and provide for their respective families. With this loan, the women of Group Dagan hope to restock their supply of yams, grains, vegetables various animals for the preparation of dishes to sell in the market. Their food is very popular and they hope that this loan will help them to satisfy the demands of their customers, enlarge their clientele and improve the quality of all of their lives.

loan.use: To restock their supply of yams, grains, vegetables and various animals for the preparation of food

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 24, 2008)

loan.name: Zehra

texts.en: Zehra was born in 1959 and she is married. Her husband has a private job and his monthly income is 950,00KM. They have 2 children. Zehra wants to use this loan of 700,00KM ($575 USD) to buy poultry, in order to improve and expand her business.

loan.use: For buying poultry.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Tabia

texts.en: Tabia is 29 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 2 years old. Tabi owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 9am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $75 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more food for her business.

loan.name: Mirela

texts.en:
Mirela was born in ÄŒivÄije and she is married. Her husband has a full time job and his monthly salary is 500,00KM. Mirela has two children, 7 and 4 years old. Their additional income is their children's allowance.

Mirela wants to use this loan of 600,00KM ($500 USD) to buy a motorized saw in order to expand her business. Her husband does the felling and he can earn additional money for their household.

loan.use: To buy a power saw

loan.name: Mary's Bombo North Group

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with 6 children. Mary owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatuma and Veronica, who sell cloth.

loan.use: To buy more food items for her business

loan.name: Marian

texts.en:
Marian S. lives in Era Community, not too far from Volk, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells rubber sandals and has been in business since 1998. Marian is 38 years of age, married, and has 4 children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for 2 years.

She needs a loan of $875 to buy more shoes to sell. She said the loan will help her to improve her business and make more profit. She thanks you.

loan.use: To buy more shoe for sale

loan.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina was born in 1966 and she lives with her husband and two children in Klokotnica, a suburb of the town of Doboj. Her husband is a demobilized soldier and he is unemployed. Mina works in a factory as a tyipist. Her husband gets an additional salary of 150 KM per month as a demobilized soldier. One of her sons attends university and the other one attends secondary school.

This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM. Mina intends to use it to buy food for her livestock. Her wish is to expand her livestock business in order to increase her monthly income.

loan.use: For buying food for the livestock.

loan.name: Judith's Muungano South Group

texts.en:
Judith is 29 years old and is a single woman. Judith is a tailor. She started in 1999. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Jetsina, who also has a tailoring business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Saumu

texts.en: Saumu is 27 years old and is a single woman. Saumu owns a small shop that she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loan.use: To buy more items for her business.

loan.name: Zilka

texts.en: Zilka was born in 1968 and she is married. Her husband is a locksmith and his monthly salary is KM 400, 00. They have 3 children, ages 11, 12 and 18. Zilka wants to use this loan for 600,00KM to buy a calf to expand her business as well as her income.

loan.use: To buy a calf

loan.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin O. hails from ikundo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She and her elder sister combined their finances to buy a machine that they both to produce nylon. She has been in this business since 1993 and she acquired the skill after one year. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She is soliciting a loan of $875 to buy more material for nylon production.

loan.use: To buy more materials for nylon production

loan.name: Almira

texts.en: Almira was born in 1978 and she is not married. She lives alone in a small place called Orahovica. She earns 300,00KM monthly from agriculture work. In the period when she is not employed, Almira sells cosmetics. She wants to use this loan for 1000, 00KM for growing potatoes to enlarge her business and earn additional income.

loan.use: For growing potatoes.

loan.name: Fadila

texts.en:
Fadila was born in 1957 and she is married. Her husband is a pensioner and he also does agriculture work. He can earn about 400 KM monthly. His monthly pension is 280 KM. They have two children, 22 and 30 years old.

This is her first loan of 1000 KM. Fadila will use it to expand her barn. She hopes to be able to expand her business.

loan.use: For expanding the barn.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta E. lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells weave-ons and hair-lengthening attachments in her area. She acquired the skill after 1 year and has been in business since 2004. She is 35 years of age and has 3 children. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy more hair attachments and weave-ons to sell.

loan.use: To buy hair attachments for her salon.

loan.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima was born in 1958 and she is married. She has one daughter, who is 15 years old. Her husband is a seasonal worker who works with a tractor. His monthly salary is KM 350, 00. When her husband is not employed, he buys vegetables that they grow. Their additional income is a pension from her father-in-law of KM 280, 00.

Tima wants to use this loan for 1000, 00KM to buy cattle to expand her business.

loan.use: To buy cattle.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Refija

texts.en:
Refija was born in 1951, and she lives in GraÄanica. She is married and has 3 daughters, ages 33, 34 and 36. Her husband has a full time job at the Eurodom construction firm and his monthly salary is KM 900,00.
Refija wants to use this loan for 1000, 00 KM to buy a calf. Her wish is to expand her business and sign a contract with a dairy.

loan.use: For buying a calf.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana M. sells cooked food and drinks in Afro Media, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old, married, and has 3 kids. Christiana acquired the skill of trading in 3 years and has been in business since 1993. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to enable her buy more drinks and food to sell.

loan.use: To buy more food and drink to sell.

loan.name: Munevera

texts.en:
Munevera is a 31-year-old woman from BabiÄ‡i, a small village near the town GraÄanica. She is married and she has two children, ages 7 and 10 years old, who go to primary school.

This is her third loan from MCO WWI (Women for Women International). The first loan was for 5 000 KM, the second loan was for 1000 KM and this loan is for 500 KM. Munevera is taking this loan to buy food for her livestock. Her wish is to expand her livestock business.

loan.use: To buy food for livestock.

loan.name: Latifa

texts.fr:
Born on December 31, 1970, in Tchaoudjo in Togo, Ms. Latifa A. is married and the mother of three. She is an energetic woman and professionally manages her fashion boutique "Intellect Couture" that she created in 1990. She still includes the sale of pagnes (colorful print fabrics) and sewing-related items in her primary business. The first loan of 300,000 francs CFA that she obtained enabled her to acquire an extra sewing machine and an overcasting (stitching) machine. After having repaid her first loan without incident, she is requesting at present a loan of 400,000 francs CFA to buy 25 bolts of pagnes, 10 rolls of cloth, and a dozen rolls of decorative lace.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Kouessoua

texts.fr:
Miss Kouessoua K. was born on June 5, 1966 in Niamey, Niger. She is single and is the breadwinner for four persons. Her primary business activity is the sale of lengths of African print cloth in the big open-air market in LomÃ©. She has been in this business for more than 10 years.

In view of Miss Kouessoua K.'s experience in this line of work, she was able to obtain her first loan of US$ 1200 which she reimbursed in a timely fashion. Her large assortment of various African prints works to attract her clientele, and she is thus able to meet her needs with the income from her business.

This second loan of US$ 1200 wil allow her to purchase 50 lengths of "fanci"-style print cloth for her inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella F.â€™s business is growing every day. This can be seen by the rapid increase in her daily sales. She used to fry yams and potatoes, but for the past two years she has been selling cooked food, because LAPO Microfinance has come to her financial aid.

She is 43 years old, married, and has 4 children. She comes from Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. Stella is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more yams, potatoes, and food to sell. She said this will help her to serve her customers better.

loan.use: To buy more yams, potatoes, and food item

loan.name: Fadila

texts.en:
Fadila is a 54-year-old woman from the town of GraÄanica. She is divorced and she has one child, who is 25 years old. She has a pension in the amount of 280 KM.
This is her first loan and its is for 1000 KM. Fadila intends to use this loan to buy chickens. She wishes to expand the business that she started with chickens.

loan.use: To buy chicken.

loan.name: Zoraida

texts.en: Zoraida was born in 1953 and she is married. Her husband has a full-time job and his monthly income is KM 1500, 00. This is the first time they have taken a loan. The amount of the current loan is KM 1200, 00. Zoraida wants to use it to buy chicken and turkey, in order to improve her business and allow her to sell poultry at the market.

loan.use: For buying chicken and turkey.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Mirjana

texts.en:
Mirjana was born in 1986 and she is not married. Her additional monthly income is KM 300, 00.

Her previous loan was for 1200, 00KM. Mirjana wants to use the current loan of KM 1200, 00 to buy additional equipment for her computer. She wants to improve her writing of graduation and seminar papers and to expand her bookkeeping and other computer-related work.

loan.use: For buying additional equipment for the computer.

loan.name: Aleksandra

texts.en: Aleksandra was born in 1984 and she is not married. She lives with her family in East Sarajevo. She is a student and she receives a monthly stipend of 100 KM. This is her first loan, and it is for 1200 KM. Aleksandra will use it to buy additional clothes for her boutique where she works. She wishes to expand the business and open her own boutique because she wants to be independent.

loan.use: To buy clothes for the boutique.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Jehova Provee Group

texts.en:
Josefina lives in S. Pedro D. Macoris with her husband and six children (ages: 21,16,15,12, 9, 4). Currently she is running a small salon, and selling both sheets and curtains to families in her community or other passers-by. She wants to use this loan to buy materials to make sheets and curtains for her little shop. Josefinaâ€™s dream for the future is to own her own cafeteria, where she can prepare and sell food to people for breakfast and lunch. She said that her main struggle right now is saving up enough money to start the cafeteria, but she believes that it will happen soon.

This is the first loan that these ten people of Jehova Provee are applying for, and they are excited to see it go to good use in their various business and homes. We all want to extend our thanks to Kiva for continually supporting the people of the Dominican Republic. God bless!

loan.use: To buy material for sheets and curtains.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence D.â€™s business is booming, because she has all it takes to satisfy her customers, ranging from provisions, drinks and food. She acquired the skill of trading in 2 years and has been in the business since 1993. She is 55 years old, married, and has 2 children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years.

Florence needs a loan of $450 to buy a generator so that she can cool all of her drinks in case there is a power failure, that is, when the Power Holding Company of Nigeria (PHCN) fails to supply electricity. She thanks you.

loan.use: To buy a generator

loan.name: Sanja

texts.en:
Sanja is a 22-year-old woman from East Sarajevo. She is not married and she lives with her parents.

Sanja will use this loan for 1000 KM for purchase on wholesale trade more plastic dishes, vases and other plastic items for household that she resells. She has a shop where she is retailing these items. Her wish is to expand the business in order to employ more people and to become a self-employed woman.

loan.use: For purchase more material.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 24, 2008)

Born on June 24, 1970 in WoamÃ© (a town situated 135 kilometers from LomÃ©), Mrs. Akouvi DÃ©lali, wife of A. E. S., has four children who are all enrolled in school. After having been in the cereals business around 1994, she began to sell lengths of African print cloth and boubous (traditional African clothing) in 2005 in the HÃ©dzranawoÃ© market in LomÃ©. Ever since she took up this business venture, she has been able to help her husband pay their children's school fees.

The loan that she is presently requesting, her first, will permit her to purchase 10 lengths of GTP African print cloth (a mid-quality brand) so that she can diversify her inventory of various prints.

loan.name: Mariama

texts.fr:
Mrs. E. Mariama was born on January 23, 1986 in LomÃ©. She is a travelling saleswoman and re-sells fabric and shoes in the district of Nukafu in LomÃ©. On average, she walks up to twelve (12) kilometers per day. With this first credit in the amount of $1,200, she plans to start a jewelery business.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Elle parcourt Ã  pieds en moyenne une distance de douze (12) kilomÃ¨tres par jour. Avec le premier crÃ©dit quâ€™elle sollicite dâ€™un montant de 500.000 FCFA, elle envisage dÃ©buter le commerce de bijoux.

loan.name: Confort

texts.en:
Confort A. is a trader who deals in jewels. She is married and has 5 dependents. Confort is a very hard-working woman who is helping her husband with the familyâ€™s expenses. She wishes to increase sales to increase her income.

She is asking for $325 as additional capital to buy more jewels for sale.

loan.use: As additional capital to buy more jewels for sale.

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43921

loan.name: Kossi Lolo

texts.fr:
Mr D. Kossi Lolo was born on June 30, 1972 in LomÃ©. He is married and is a father of two (2) children. In 2003, he started a copying/office supplies business in the district of AgoÃ¨, where he also sells stationery for schools. In 2007, due to the success of his business, he created a second shop in the district of AdidoadÃ© in LomÃ©.
